title: Meeting the design challenges of the nano-CMOS electronics
impactText: A number of conference and journal publications have results from the work undertaken on this project. Some follow-on funding was obtained to take some of the result of the project closer to commercialisation. Following on from this a University spin-out company was formed in 2012. Digital/Communication/Information Technologies (including Software),Education,Electronics Economic
findingsText:
Using the developed simulation methodology and the database of compact device and circuit level compact models made available across the Grid infrastructure within this large multi-institutional project, we studied the impact of next generation technologies, and related parameter fluctuations, on the design of digital circuits. During the project we developed:
o Evolutionary techniques to be used within device models to alleviate parameter fluctuation problems.
o Showed how parameter variation datasets can be best used by evolutionary techniques to improve system performance.
o Illustrated how evolutionary techniques can be used to limit the effects of parameter variations. The developments within this project showed that novel evolutionary methods can be used to give real and important improvements to microelectronics design, particularly when faced with variability. This has been exploited through a University spin-out company. Digital/Communication/Information Technologies (including Software),Education,Electronics
